title: Hilbert's 15th Problem: Schubert Calculus
description: Rigorous foundation of Schubert's enumerative calculus for counting geometric configurations in Grassmannians.

overview.historicalContext: Schubert (1879) developed counting techniques for geometric configurations. Hilbert asked to make these rigorous. The problem was resolved through intersection theory on Grassmannians.
overview.problemStatement:
**Problem:** Rigorously justify Schubert's counting methods.

**Classic Results:**
- 2 lines meet 4 given lines in 3D
- 3264 conics tangent to 5 conics
- 27 lines on a cubic surface
overview.proofStrategy:
The formalization uses:
1. Grassmannians as parameter spaces
2. Incidence conditions as linear constraints
3. Intersection theory for counting
keyInsights: Schubert classes form a cohomology basis

sections.title: Grassmannians
sections.summary: Definition of Grassmannians via linear algebra.

sections.title: Four Lines Theorem
sections.summary: Exactly 2 lines meet 4 generic lines in 3D.

conclusion.summary: Hilbert's 15th Problem was resolved by developing rigorous intersection theory on Grassmannians. Schubert's counting methods are now justified.
conclusion.implications: Schubert calculus is fundamental to enumerative geometry and has applications in physics (string theory) and combinatorics.
openQuestions: Can Schubert calculus be computed efficiently?
What are the connections to representation theory?
How does this extend to other homogeneous spaces?
